awd_titl_txt: Advancing the Cognitive Science of Active Learning: Pinpointing Instructional Features that Maximize Equity, Self-Efficacy, and Student Learning in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

This postdoctoral research fellowship project will investigate how active learning can be effectively integrated into lectures to promote equity, self-efficacy, and student learning in STEM courses. By conducting the research at a Hispanic-Serving Institution with a diverse student population, the fellow is in a position to produce insights into instructional practices that enhance the academic success of groups of students who are underrepresented in their participation in STEM fields of study. A professional development plan is in place that is tailored to the career goals of the fellow and includes activities that will enable the fellow to deepen knowledge and skills related to conducting theoretically driven and applied research. This in turn lays the groundwork for a future research career of developing evidence-based teaching guidelines for college instructors. 

This research study will include three experiments that manipulate the dosage schedule and order of active learning and lecture to assess the impact of active learning on student success in introductory STEM coursework. The manipulation of dosage schedule will involve blocking active learning and lecture and interspersing active learning and lecture. The manipulation of dosage order will provide (a) lecture first and active learning second and (b) active learning first and lecture second. The first two experiments will occur in an highly controlled laboratory environment and the third experiment will occur in an introductory biology class co-taught by two biology professors. Students in the three experiments will learn biology concepts in four different instructional conditions, and their level of success in these conditions will be measured using self-efficacy and learning instruments. A comparison between underrepresented and non-underrepresented students on their self-efficacy ratings and learning scores will also be conducted to examine whether there are any proportionate or disproportionate gains or losses. The results of the study could be used to guide college course transformations by producing evidence about how to implement active learning effectively,

The project responds to the STEM Education Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (STEM Ed PRF) program that aims to enhance the research knowledge, skills, and practices of recent doctorates in STEM, STEM education, education, and related disciplines to advance their preparation to engage in fundamental and applied research that advances knowledge within the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The funded project through the STEM Education Postdoctoral Research Fellowship Program was designed to examine the most effective way to implement active learning activities in the context of STEM lectures. The primary goals of this project were to broaden participation in STEM and provide insight into effective ways to effectively implement active learning in the STEM classroom. An important step in addressing STEM disparities and broadening participation is to determine how to implement active learning in STEM education to better support students from diverse backgrounds. 

This project provided insight into how to integrate active learning into STEM lectures by examining the effects of dosage schedule (i.e., whether lecture and active learning should be alternated during class or presented as independent units), order (i.e., whether active learning or lecture should be presented first or second), and amount (i.e., how much time should be dedicated to active learning vs. lecture during class) and the potential interaction between/among these factors. Results of a classroom study run in a large biology course indicated that different sequences of these two instructional methods had similar effects on student learning and self-efficacy. In this study, students learned four biology concepts in four different instructional conditions (blocked, lecture first; blocked, active learning first; interspersed, lecture first; and interspersed, active learning first), and their level of success in these conditions was measured using self-efficacy and learning instruments. Additionally, results of a classroom study conducted in a large research methodology course indicated that the effectiveness of different amounts of active learning and lecture may depend on the nature of the content being taught, with more time for active learning being particularly beneficial for an easier topic as compared to a more difficult topic. Impacts of the instructional conditions differed for some demographic variables such as major and parent(s)’ highest level of education. 

Additional studies that are nearing completion include a lab-based study investigating dosage order and schedule—similar to the biology classroom study. Further, two experiments examining the use of immersive virtual reality (IVR) to encourage active learning have been designed and implemented in the lab to investigate if and when IVR is useful for learning and to determine how to sequence instruction within an IVR lesson.

In addition to conducting experimental studies, the funding afforded the opportunity for several systematic reviews to be conducted/completed. One systematic review examined the rigor of active learning research in STEM education and found that much of this literature base is confounded. Two additional systematic reviews examined (a) the rigor of IVR research in STEM education and (b) the control or confounding of methods and media. Results indicated the IVR literature also has areas that need to be addressed when it comes to internal validity and the control and isolation of critical variables. Finally, three additional reviews were conducted to examine trends within the fields of educational psychology and educational technology. All of these reviews were designed to serve researchers in designing rigorous studies related to active learning and to highlight patterns within the field for a view of where we have been and where we are going.

Results from the project have been shared in publication outlets (e.g., Educational Psychology Review, Education Sciences) and at conferences (e.g., AERA, APA). The results of the project have been in service of (a) providing specific guidance to instructors on how to implement active learning in their courses to maximize student success and (b) highlighting ways researchers can conduct future research to fill gaps in the literature and improve the methodological rigor of studies conducted in STEM education.
